Chapter 12: The Nature of the TathÄgata
KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Are there selves in the twenty-five existences?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
The self is the meaning of the TathÄgatagarbha.
All sentient beings have buddha-nature, which is the meaning of self.

It is like a poor woman whose house contains a great treasure of true gold, but neither the family members nor anyone else knows about it.
At that time, a different person who was skilled in methods said to the poor woman:
'I will now hire you to weed and remove the impurities for me.'
The woman immediately replied:
'I am not able to do that now.
If you can show me my son's gold treasure, then I will quickly do it for you.'
This person said again:
'I know a way to show you my son.'
The woman replied:
'My family, young and old, do not even know about it, let alone you being able to know.'
This person said again:
'I am now truly able to.'
The woman replied:
'I also want to see it, so you can show it to me.'
This person then dug out the gold treasure from her house.
Seeing it, the woman was overjoyed and had a sense of awe for this person.
Good man!
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. All sentient beings cannot see it, just like the poor person who does not know about the treasure.
Good man!
I now universally reveal to all sentient beings the buddha-nature they possess, which is obscured by afflictions, like the poor man who cannot see his true gold treasure.
The TathÄgata today universally reveals to sentient beings the treasure of enlightenment, which is called the buddha-nature.
All sentient beings, having seen this, give rise to joy and look up to the TathÄgata.
The one with skillful means is the TathÄgata;
The poor woman is the innumerable sentient beings;
The true gold treasure is the buddha-nature.
Moreover, good man!
It is like a woman who gives birth to a child.
When the infant falls ill, the woman is worried and seeks out a skilled doctor.
When the skilled doctor arrives, he combines three kinds of medicineâ€”clarified butter, milk, and honeyâ€”and has the child take it.
He then tells the woman:ğŸ”½'After the child has taken the medicine, do not give him milk right away.
Wait until the medicine has been digested before giving it to him.
At that time, the woman would apply a bitter substance to her breasts and tell her child:
My milk has been poisoned and cannot be touched.
The child, thirsty and hungry, wanting to drink the mother's milk, would stay far away upon smelling the poisonous smell of the milk.
When the medicine was digested, the mother would wash her breasts and call the child to come and drink.
Although the child was still hungry and thirsty, it would not come because of having previously smelled the poisonous smell.
The mother would then say:
Because you had taken medicine, I applied poison to my breasts.
Now that your medicine has been digested, I have washed them clean. You may come and drink without any pain.
Hearing this, the child would gradually return to drink.
Good man!
The Tathagata is also like this. In order to save all, he teaches sentient beings to cultivate the Dharma of no-self.
Having cultivated in this way, they permanently sever the mind of self and enter nirvana.

In order to eliminate the world's false views, to manifest transcendence over worldly dharmas, and to show that the world's attachment to a self is false and not real, in order to cultivate the pure body of the dharma of no-self.
It is like a woman who, for the sake of her child, smears bitter-tasting substances on her breasts.
The TathÄgata is also like this. For the sake of cultivating emptiness, he says:
All dharmas are without a self.
Just as that woman, after washing her breasts, calls out to her child, wanting it to drink again.
I am also like this now, speaking of the TathÄgatagarbha.
Therefore, bhiká¹£us should not give rise to fear.
Just as that infant, hearing its mother's call, gradually drinks her milk again.
Bhiká¹£us are also like this. They should discern for themselves that the TathÄgata's secret treasury is not nonexistent.
Bodhisattva MahÄkÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
There truly is no self.
Why is it so?
When an infant is born, it knows nothing.
If there were a self, then on the day of birth one should immediately have awareness.
For this reason, it is definitely known that there is no self.
If there were definitely a self, then after being born one should not have an end.
If it is the case that all have buddha-nature, which is permanent, then there should be no characteristics of destruction.
If there are no characteristics of destruction, how can there be distinctions of ká¹£atriyas, brahmins, vaiÅ›yas, Å›Å«dras, caá¹‡á¸Älas, and animals?
Now, it is seen that karmic conditions are of various kinds, and the destinies are each different.
If there were definitely a self, then all sentient beings should have no differences in victory or defeat.
For this reason, it is definitely known that buddha-nature is not a permanent dharma.

If it is said that buddha-nature is definitely permanent, then why is it also said that there are killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, divisive speech, harsh speech, false speech, frivolous speech, greed, anger, and wrong views?
If the nature of the self is permanent, then why does one become intoxicated and confused after drinking alcohol?
If the self is permanent, the blind should be able to see forms, the deaf should be able to hear sounds, the mute should be able to speak, and the paralyzed should be able to walk.
If the self is permanent, one should not avoid fire pits, great waters, poisonous substances, swords, evil people, or wild animals.
If the self is permanent, one should not forget past experiences.
If one does not forget, why would one say:
'Where have I seen this person before?'
If the self is permanent, there should be no aging, youth, flourishing, decline, or recollection of past events.
If the self is permanent, where does it abide?
Is it in the various colors of snot, phlegm, yellow, red, and white?
If the self is permanent, it should pervade the body, like sesame oil, with no empty spaces.
If the body is severed, the self should also be severed.
The Buddha told KÄÅ›yapa:
Good man!
It is like a powerful wrestler in the king's palace who has a vajra jewel between his eyebrows.
When wrestling with another wrestler, the other wrestler bumps his head against him, and the jewel on his forehead immediately sinks into his skin, and he does not know where the jewel is at all.
There is a wound at the place of the jewel, so he summons a good doctor to treat it.
At that time, there is a skilled doctor who is well-versed in medicine and knows that the wound is caused by the jewel entering the body, and the jewel has entered the skin and stopped there.
The skilled doctor then asks the wrestler:
Where is the jewel on your forehead?
The wrestler is startled and replies:
Great master doctor!
Has the jewel on my forehead been lost?
Where is that jewel now?
Is it not an illusion?
He grieves and cries.
At that time, the skilled doctor consoles the wrestler:
You should not give rise to great sorrow and distress now.
When you were fighting, the precious pearl entered your body and is now inside your skin, casting a shadow outside.
When you were fighting, your anger was so intense that the pearl sank into your body, so you did not notice it yourself.
At that time, the strong men did not believe the doctor's words:
If it were inside the skin, how could pus and blood not come out?
If it were inside the muscles, it should not be visible.
How can you deceive us now?
Then the doctor took a mirror and held it up to his face, and the pearl appeared clearly in the mirror.
When the strong man saw it, he was astonished and amazed.
Good man!

All sentient beings are also like this. Because they cannot be close to good and wise advisors, although they have Buddha-nature, they cannot see it. They are covered by greed, anger, and ignorance, and therefore fall into hell, animal realms, hungry ghost realms, asura realms, candala, kshatriya, brahmin, vaisya, and sudra families, and are born in such various families.
Because of the various karmic conditions arising from the mind, although they receive human bodies, they are deaf, blind, mute, paralyzed, and crippled.
In the twenty-five realms of existence, they receive various karmic retributions. Greed, anger, and ignorance cover their minds, and they do not know Buddha-nature.
It is like that strong man whose precious pearl is on his body but he thinks he has lost it.

Sentient beings are also like this. Because they do not know how to be close to good and wise advisors, they do not recognize the Tathagata's subtle and secret treasure store, and practice the study of no-self.
It is like non-sages, although they speak of self, they also do not know the true nature of self.
My disciples are also like this. Because they do not know how to be close to good and virtuous friends, they cultivate the study of non-self, and also do not know the place of non-self.
They themselves do not know the true nature of non-self, let alone be able to know the true nature of self.
Good man!
The TathÄgata thus speaks of all sentient beings having Buddha-nature, like the skilled doctor showing the powerful man the vajra jewel.
These sentient beings are obscured by immeasurable hundreds of thousands of afflictions and do not recognize Buddha-nature.
If they exhaust the afflictions, then they will be able to realize and clearly know it, like the powerful man seeing his jewel in the bright mirror.
Good man!
The secret treasury of the TathÄgata is like this - immeasurable and inconceivable.
Furthermore, good man!

It is like a snow mountain having a one-flavored medicine called joyful taste, whose flavor is extremely sweet. It is under thick vegetation, and people cannot see it. Someone who smells the fragrance immediately knows that there should be this medicine in that place.
In the past, there was a wheel-turning king who, for the sake of this medicine, built wooden containers everywhere in the snow mountains to receive the medicine.
When the medicine matured, it flowed out from the ground and gathered in the wooden containers, its flavor truly genuine.
After the king passed away, the medicine later became either sour, salty, sweet, bitter, spicy, or bland.
Thus, the one flavor, following where it flowed, had various differences. The true flavor of the medicine remained on the mountain like a full moon.
Ordinary people with meager blessings, even if they dig and exert great effort, cannot obtain it.
Furthermore, there was a sage king who appeared in the world, and due to the causes and conditions of his blessings, he obtained the true flavor of the medicine.
Good man!
The flavor of the TathÄgata's secret treasury is also like this. It is covered by the thicket of afflictions, and ignorant beings are unable to see it.

The single flavor of the medicine is a metaphor for the Buddha-nature. Due to afflictions, it produces various flavors, namely, the realms of hell, animals, hungry ghosts, gods, humans, males, females, non-male, non-female, ká¹£atriyas, brahmins, vaiÅ›yas, and Å›Å«dras.
The Buddha-nature is vigorous and difficult to destroy, and therefore there is no one who can kill it.
If there were someone who could kill it, they would sever the Buddha-nature. In this way, the Buddha-nature is ultimately indestructible.
If the nature could be severed, there would be no such possibility.
My nature is precisely the secret treasury of the TathÄgata.
Such a secret treasury cannot be destroyed or burned by anyone.
Although it cannot be destroyed, it cannot be seen. If one attains supreme perfect enlightenment, only then can one realize it.
For these reasons, there is no one who can kill.
Bodhisattva MahÄkÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If there is no killer, there should be no unwholesome karma.
The Buddha told KÄÅ›yapa:
There truly is killing.
Why is it so?
Good man!
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings abides within the five aggregates. If one destroys the five aggregates, it is called killing.

If there is killing, one will fall into an evil realm. Due to karmic causes and conditions, there are distinctions such as ká¹£atriyas, brahmins, vaiÅ›yas, Å›Å«dras, and caá¹‡á¸Älas, males, females, non-males, and non-females, and the twenty-five forms of existence, transmigrating through birth and death.
Non-sage people falsely conceive of a self, imagining its size to be like a grain of millet, a grain of rice, or even a thumb. Such various false thoughts have no true reality.
The self-nature of the supramundane is called buddha-nature. Thinking of the self in this way is called the best.
Moreover, good man!

It is like a person who knows well how to dig for treasures. He takes a sharp hoe and digs straight down, passing through rocks, sand, and gravel without difficulty, only reaching the diamond cannot be penetrated.

For this reason, destroying the five aggregates is called killing.
Good man!
You must definitely know that the Buddha Dharma is like this, inconceivable.
Good man!
The Vaipulya sÅ«tras are like nectar and also like poison.
Bodhisattva MahÄkÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
For what reason did the TathÄgata say that the Vaipulya sÅ«tras are like nectar and also like poison?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Do you now wish to know the true meaning of the TathÄgata's secret treasury?
MahÄkÄÅ›yapa said:

At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
Some who ingest nectar will lose their lives and die young;
Some who ingest nectar will have long lives;

The nectar of unobstructed wisdom is called the MahÄyÄna canon;
This MahÄyÄna canon is also called mixed poisonous medicine.
Like ghee, cream, and other types of rock candy,

The foolish do not know Buddha-nature, and taking it becomes poison.
For the Sravakas and Pratyekabuddhas, the Mahayana is nectar;
Just as among all flavors, milk is the best.
Thus, those who diligently progress, relying on the Mahayana,
Attain nirvana, becoming the king of men.
Beings who know Buddha-nature, like Kashyapa and others,
Have the unsurpassed flavor of nectar, neither born nor dying.
Kashyapa!
You should now skillfully distinguish the three refuges. The nature of these three refuges is my nature.
If one can carefully observe, my nature has Buddha-nature,
One should know that such a person can enter the secret treasury;
Knowing the self and what belongs to the self, this person has already transcended the world.
The nature of the Buddha, Dharma, and Three Jewels, the unsurpassed and foremost honored one,
The nature of the meaning of the verses I have spoken is like this.

Please explain it to me.ğŸ”½How does one attain mastery?
How does one not attain mastery?
How does one take refuge in the Saá¹…gha and attain the unsurpassed benefit?

If one does not attain it in the future, how can one take refuge in the Three Jewels?
I now have no prior knowledge, so I will proceed in order.
How can one who is not pregnant have the thought of giving birth?
If one is definitely in the womb, then one is said to have a child;
If the child is in the womb, it will definitely be born soon,
This is called the meaning of child;
The karma of sentient beings is also like this.

Because of their lack of understanding, they revolve in the prison of birth and death.
The one who is called an upÄsaka does not understand the true meaning,
I only wish that you will extensively distinguish and sever the net of my doubts.
The TathÄgata's great wisdom, I only pray that you will compassionately distinguish,
Please explain the secret treasure store of the TathÄgata.
KÄÅ›yapa!
You should know that I will now for you well open the subtle secret treasury, enabling you to sever your doubts.
Now listen with utmost sincerity:
You will then be the seventh buddha, with the same name as the bodhisattvas.
Those who take refuge in the Buddha are truly called upÄsakas,
They will never again take refuge in other gods;
Those who take refuge in the Dharma will then avoid killing;
Those who take refuge in the noble Sangha will not seek out non-Buddhist paths.
Thus, taking refuge in the Three Jewels, one attains fearlessness.
KÄÅ›yapa said to the Buddha:
I also take refuge in the Three Jewels, which are called the right path, the realm of all buddhas.
The equal characteristics of the Three Jewels are always endowed with great wisdom-nature,
The nature of self and the nature of the Buddha are non-dual and without distinction.
This path is praised by the Buddha, the place of right progress and peace,
It is also called right and universal vision, thus it is praised by the Buddha.
I too will pursue the praised unsurpassed path of the Sugata,
Which is the sweetest nectar, with nothing else like it.
At that time, the Buddha told Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa:
Good man!
You should not now, like the Å›rÄvakas and ordinary people, discriminate the Three Jewels.
In this MahÄyÄna there are no characteristics of discrimination in the Three Refuges.
Why is it so?

Within buddha-nature there is the Dharma and the Saá¹ƒgha. In order to transform and liberate the Å›rÄvakas and ordinary people, the different characteristics of the Three Jewels are discriminated and explained.
Good man!
If one wishes to accord with the dharmas of the world, one should discriminate that there are three refuges.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas should contemplate like this:
'My present body takes refuge in the Buddha.'
If this very body attains the path of buddhahood, and having attained buddhahood, it should not revere, bow to, or make offerings to the various world-honored ones.
Why is it so?
Because all Buddhas are equal, equally becoming refuges for sentient beings.
If one wishes to revere the Dharma body relics, one should then pay homage to the Buddha's stupas.
Why is it so?
In order to transform and liberate all sentient beings, and also to cause sentient beings to give rise to the thought of stupas in my body and make offerings to it.
In this way, sentient beings will take my Dharma body as their refuge.
All sentient beings rely on false and deviant dharmas. I should explain the true Dharma in sequence for them;
There are also those who take refuge in the non-true Sangha. I should make them rely on the true Sangha;
If there are those who distinguish the three refuges, I should make them have a single refuge, without the distinction of three;
For the blind, I will be their eyes;
I will also be the true refuge for the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
Good man!
In this way, the bodhisattva performs the Buddha's work for innumerable evil beings and the wise.
Good man!
It is like a person who, when facing a battle, gives rise to the thought:
'I am the foremost here. All the soldiers rely on me.'
It is also like a crown prince who thinks like this:
'I should subdue the other princes, succeed to the great king's imperial work, and attain freedom, causing all the princes to see and take refuge.'
Therefore, one should not give rise to an inferior mind, just as a king, prince, or minister should be.
Good man!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is also like this. He thinks like this:
'How can the three matters be of one essence with me?'
Good man!
I show that the three matters are precisely nirvÄá¹‡a.
The TathÄgata is called the unsurpassed person.
It is like a person's body, where the head is the most superior, not the other limbs, hands, feet, etc.
The Buddha is also like this, being the most venerable, not the Dharma or the Saá¹…gha.
In order to transform and liberate the worldly, he manifests various different appearances, like a ladder.
Therefore, you should not now uphold the distinctions of the Three Refuges as known by ordinary foolish people. You should be like a sharp sword in your fierce determination towards the Mahayana.
Bodhisattva MahÄkÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
I ask out of understanding, not out of ignorance.

I ask on behalf of the greatly courageous bodhisattvas about the place of practice that is free from defilements and pure, wishing for the TathÄgata to extensively proclaim and elucidate the extraordinary matters and extol the MahÄyÄna Vaipulya sÅ«tras.
The TathÄgata's great compassion has now been well spoken, and I will also abide within it.
The pure practices of the bodhisattvas that are explained are precisely the proclamation of the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra.
World-Honored One!
I will now also extensively reveal and proclaim this TathÄgata's secret treasury for the sake of sentient beings, and I will also realize and know the true refuge.
If there are sentient beings who can believe in this MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra, those people will naturally understand the three refuges.
Why is this?
Because the TathÄgata's secret treasury has buddha-nature.
Those who proclaim this sÅ«tra all say:
'The body is completely endowed with buddha-nature.'
Such people will not seek the three refuges far away.
Why is this?
In the future, my body will precisely accomplish the Three Jewels.
Therefore, the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and other sentient beings will all rely on me to pay homage and make offerings.

For this reason, one should correctly study the MahÄyÄna sÅ«tras.
KÄÅ›yapa said again:
The Buddha-nature is inconceivable like this, and the thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks are also inconceivable.
At that time, the Buddha praised KÄÅ›yapa Bodhisattva, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
You have already accomplished profound and sharp wisdom. I will now further explain to you the entry into the TathÄgata's storehouse.
If I abide, then it is a permanent dharma, not apart from suffering;
If there is no self, then cultivating pure practices is of no benefit.
If it is said that all dharmas are without self, then this is the view of annihilation;
If it is said that the self abides, then this is the view of permanence.
If it is said that all conditioned things are impermanent, then this is the view of annihilation;
If conditioned things are permanent, then this is the view of permanence.
If it is said to be suffering, then this is the view of annihilation;
If it is said to be happiness, then this is the view of permanence.
Cultivating all dharmas as permanent falls into the view of annihilation;
Those who cultivate the cessation of all dharmas fall into the view of eternalism.
Just as a centipede must rely on its front legs to move its hind legs;
The cultivation of permanence and cessation is also like this, it must rely on cessation and permanence.
For this reason, the cultivation of the suffering of other dharmas is all called unwholesome;
The cultivation of the bliss of other dharmas is then called wholesome.
The cultivation of the non-self of other dharmas is the aspect of all afflictions;
The cultivation of the permanence of other dharmas is then called the secret treasury of the TathÄgata, namely nirvÄá¹‡a without a dwelling place.
The cultivation of other impermanent dharmas is then one's possessions;
The cultivation of other permanent dharmas refers to the Buddha, Dharma, Saá¹ƒgha, and correct liberation.
One should know that such a middle way in the Buddha Dharma is free from the two extremes and expounds the true Dharma. Ordinary foolish people have no doubts about this.
Just as a weak patient, after taking ghee, becomes light and agile.
The nature of the dharmas of existence and non-existence is not fixed.
It is like the four great elements, whose natures are different and mutually opposed.
A good doctor knows well how to treat them according to their excesses.
Good sons!

The TathÄgata is also like this, being like a good doctor to sentient beings. He knows the differences in the characteristics of the afflictions and eliminates them, revealing the TathÄgata's secret treasury, the pure buddha-nature that is eternally abiding and unchanging.
If it is said to exist, wisdom should not be defiled;
if it is said to not exist, that is a lie.
If it is said to exist, one should not be silent, nor should one engage in frivolous arguments. One should only seek to understand the true nature of dharmas.
Foolish people engage in frivolous arguments and disputes because they do not understand the TathÄgata's secret treasury.
If suffering is spoken of, foolish people will think:
'The body is impermanent.'
If all suffering is spoken of, they will still not understand that the body has the nature of bliss.
Those who speak of impermanence, ordinary people think that all bodies are impermanent, like pottery.
The wise should distinguish and not say that everything is impermanent.
Why is it so?
My body has the seeds of Buddha-nature.
If it is said to be without self, ordinary people will think:
'All the Buddha-dharmas are completely without self.'
The wise should distinguish that the provisional name of no-self is not real. Knowing this, one should not give rise to doubt.
If it is said that the hidden treasury of the TathÄgata is empty and tranquil, ordinary people, upon hearing it, will give rise to the view of annihilation;
The wise should distinguish that the TathÄgata is permanent and unchanging.
If it is said that liberation is like an illusion,
ordinary people will think:
'Attaining true liberation is precisely annihilation.'
The wise should distinguish that although the Lion among Men has coming and going, he is permanently abiding and unchanging.
If it is said:
'Ignorance is the condition for formations.'
When ordinary people hear this, they discriminate and give rise to the notion of two dharmas, namely, illumination and ignorance;
The wise one thoroughly understands that their nature is non-dual, and the non-dual nature is precisely the true nature.
If it is said:
'The condition of formations is consciousness,' ordinary people consider it to be two, namely, formations and consciousness;
The wise one thoroughly understands that their nature is non-dual, and the non-dual nature is precisely the true nature.
If it is said:
'The ten wholesome [deeds] and the ten unwholesome [deeds], what should be done and what should not be done, the good and evil paths, the pure and impure dharmas,'
Ordinary people consider them to be two;
The wise one thoroughly understands that their nature is non-dual, and the non-dual nature is precisely the true nature.
If it is said:
'One should cultivate the suffering of all dharmas,'
Ordinary people consider it to be two;
The wise one thoroughly understands that their nature is non-dual, and the non-dual nature is precisely the true nature.
If it is said:
'All conditioned things are impermanent' means that even the secret treasury of the TathÄgata is impermanent. Ordinary beings consider them to be two,
but the wise understand that their nature is non-dual, and the nature of non-duality is precisely the true nature.
If it is said:
'All dharmas are without self, and the secret treasury of the TathÄgata is also without self,'
ordinary beings consider them to be two,
but the wise understand that their nature is non-dual, and the nature of non-duality is precisely the true nature.
Self and non-self have no duality in nature.
The meaning of the secret treasury of the TathÄgata is like this, praised by innumerable and boundless Buddhas.
I have now explained all these merits and accomplishments in the sÅ«tra.
Good sons!
Self and non-self have no duality in nature and characteristics. You should uphold and accept this.
Good sons!
You should also firmly remember this sutra. As I have previously said in the MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ SÅ«tra:
'Self and non-self are not two different characteristics.'

Just as curd is produced from milk, fresh butter is obtained from curd, clarified butter is obtained from fresh butter, and ghee is obtained from clarified butter. In this way, the nature of curd is born from milk.
Is it born from itself or from others?
Up to ghee, it is the same.
If it is born from others, then it is created by others, not born from milk;
if it is not born from milk, then milk has no function.
If it is born from itself, then it should not be born in a similar continuous manner;
if it is born in a continuous manner, then it is not born together;
if it is not born together, then the five flavors are not born at the same time. Although not born at the same time, they definitely do not come from other places.
One should know that milk already has the characteristics of curd, but because the sweet taste is abundant, it cannot transform itself.
Up to ghee, it is also like this.
This cow eats water and grass, and through the transformation of blood vessels, it obtains milk.
If it eats sweet grass, the milk will be sweet;
if it eats bitter grass, the milk will have a bitter taste.
